headline: Who's Talking to Chris Wallace
subHeadline: Interview With Quentin Tarantino; Interview With Kara Swisher; Interview With Billy Porter. Aired 7-8p ET

utterances.speaker: KRISTIN FISHER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: And President Biden forcefully condemned the attack issuing a statement that said in part, quote, "We cannot and must not tolerate hate."Well, thank you so much for joining us me this evening. I'm in for Pamela Brown and I'm Kristin Fisher. "WHO'S TALKING TO CHRIS WALLACE?" is up next.

utterances.speaker: CHRIS WALLACE, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Welcome back to WHO'S TALKING.Tonight, we have three fascinating conversations to share with you. Each compelling in its own way. Up first, he's one of the most celebrated directors of our time, Quentin Tarantino, on his movie, his method and how he takes his audience on a ride. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: QUENTIN TARANTINO, WRITER AND DIRECTOR
utterances.sentences: Laugh, laugh, laugh, stop laughing. Stop laughing, stop laughing. No laughing. No laughing. Laugh.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And Kara Swisher is widely considered the most powerful and plugged in reporter in the world of big tech. Tonight, we ask our what's next in Silicon Valley and about Elon Musk's wild takeover of social media giant Twitter.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Is it conceivable it could just collapse?

utterances.speaker: KARA SWISHER, TECH JOURNALIST
utterances.sentences: Yes, of course.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And later, singer and actor Billy Porter shares his painful personal story and tells me about his professional redemption.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: What statement were you making there?

utterances.speaker: BILLY PORTER, ACTOR
utterances.sentences: F you all. I'm going to do exactly what I want to do.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You've had a few clunkers in recent year.

utterances.speaker: GEORGE CLOONEY, ACTOR
utterances.sentences: You think?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: That's not perception. That's reality.

utterances.speaker: SHANIA TWAIN, SINGER
utterances.sentences: I've been feeling stronger than ever now in my life.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: How would you rate yourself as a chef?

utterances.speaker: TYLER PERRY, COMEDIAN
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm not doing that with you, Christopher Wallace.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Oscar-winning director Quentin Tarantino has made some of the most highly regarded movies of the last 30 years. As he approaches a self-imposed end to his career as a director, he's out with a new book "Cinema Speculation" which chronicles some of the early films that helped shape him.We started our conversation taking a trip through Tarantino's own movies and how he developed his signature style. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: The first one you direct is "Reservoir Dogs" in 1992 and you announced your arrival on the scene with this particular moment.(CLIP FROM "RESERVOIR DOGS")

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: That's Mr. Blond torturing a cop.

utterances.speaker: TARANTINO
utterances.sentences: Yes. You cut it just before it got good.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Or would have closed the studio down. How did you come up with this idea of highly stylized violence?

utterances.speaker: TARANTINO
utterances.sentences: You know, there's all kinds of scenes that I respond to, and movies I respond to. Music sequences, I respond to big comedy sequences. It was like they galvanized the entire theater. Everybody woke up. Everybody got connected and I would go see a film that had -- a sequence like that, I would see it two or three times at the theaters just to see that sequence. And just to have that experience with an audience.So, you know, again, we're talking about, you know, you're calling it violence. You know, it is violence. It's also action. I think it's also kind of what movies do in a way that's particular to them as opposed to theater or literature is the filming of kinetic violence that can usually, usually, that can have different reasons for the impact but oftentimes give a cathartic release for an audience. WALLACE: Two years later, you make "Pulp Fiction" and there we see something else that makes you unique, which is dialogue you won't find anyplace else.

utterances.speaker: TARANTINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) SAMUEL L. JACKSON, ACTOR: What does Marcelous Wallace look like?

utterances.speaker: BRETT WHALEY, ACTOR
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: JACKSON
utterances.sentences: What country you from?

utterances.speaker: WHALEY
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: JACKSON
utterances.sentences: What ain't no country I ever heard of. They speak English in what?

utterances.speaker: WHALEY
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: JACKSON
utterances.sentences: English mother (EXPLETIVE DELETED). Do you speak it?

utterances.speaker: WHALEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JACKSON
utterances.sentences: Then you know what I'm saying?

utterances.speaker: WHALEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JACKSON
utterances.sentences: Describe what Marcelous Wallace looks like.

utterances.speaker: WHALEY
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: JACKSON
utterances.sentences: Say what again. Say what again. I dare you. I double dare you, mother (EXPLETIVE DELETED). Say what one more God damn time.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TARANTINO
utterances.sentences: I just get the characters talking to each other. So it's like me the writer is writing it and yes, I'm kind of controlling it for a while but the idea is the conversation, it catches fire amongst the characters and then they take it, and run with it. And then I'm almost like a court reporter jotting it all down, and then usually whatever comes out is what comes out.Now inside of that, there is a rhythm to it. There is a musicality to it. There is a bit of rhyme that happens between some of the words and some of the phrases, and so, you know, it's not poetry but it's not completely divorced from poetry. It's not rap but it's not completely divorced from it. It's not a standup comedy act but it's not completely divorced from that either. WALLACE: I want to show one other scene for no other reason than it's just so cool from "Pulp Fiction."

utterances.speaker: TARANTINO
utterances.sentences: Great.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: John Travolta and Uma Thurman.

utterances.speaker: TARANTINO
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: There they are.(CLIP FROM "PULP FICTION")

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: How did that come about?

utterances.speaker: TARANTINO
utterances.sentences: Everyone knows that I'm kind of -- was bringing John Travolta back from, I think, "Look Who's Talking 3" when he did the movie and it set him up for a whole second act of his career and a really third act of his career for a really lovely way, but at the time, you know, audiences would go see the film. They didn't quite know everything yet, so they're feeling, oh, John Travolta is in it. I haven't seen him in a while.So he's in a movie and he's playing a gangster and it's all going along and it's funny and it's this. Then they go to Jack Rabbit Slims and everything is interesting and it's a little funny dialogue back and forth. This is all interesting. And then, OK, and now it's time for this twist contest and Uma Thurman goes, OK, right here and then they go up there and then he takes off his shoes. And then all of a sudden, all throughout the audience of a packed theater, and this happened for a few weeks when the movie was first open, you had this little realization like, oh, my god, he's going to dance. He's actually going to dance. And then John Travolta with the biggest dance stars of the last 30 years in a movie you did not expect that to happen goes out there and cuts a rug and brings the house down.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So let's jump ahead. 2009 your World War II movie "Inglourious Basterds" and here's a scene where Aldo Rain, who's the head of the American commando unit, the Basterds, has a surprisingly civil conversation with SS Officer Hans Landa.

utterances.speaker: TARANTINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CHRISTOPH WALZ, ACTOR
utterances.sentences: So you're Aldo the Apache.

utterances.speaker: BRAD PITT, ACTOR
utterances.sentences: So you're the Jew Hunter.

utterances.speaker: WALZ
utterances.sentences: I'm a detective. A damn good detective. Finding people is my specialty so naturally I work for the Nazis finding people and yes, some of them were Jews, but Jew Hunter? Just a name that stuck.

utterances.speaker: BJ NOVAK, ACTOR
utterances.sentences: Well, you do have to admit it is catchy.(END VIDEO CLIP) (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So often in your movies instead of realism, you go for the way we wish life would be, don't you?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It's your movie.

utterances.speaker: TARANTINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Quentin Tarantino made most of his movies with Hollywood mogul Harvey Weinstein who's since then convicted of rape.Coming up, I ask him about their partnership. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Why didn't you do more to try to stop him and to protect the women?(END VIDEO CLIP) (COMMERCIAL BREAK) WALLACE: When Quentin Tarantino was 9 years old, he saw a movie in a theater where the audience was so engaged they started yelling at the screen. He says he tries to recreate that experience in his movies. We talk about that and his long working relationship with Harvey Weinstein. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I was going to say when are you going to use the word manipulate. You're not afraid of that.

utterances.speaker: TARANTINO
utterances.sentences: I got (INAUDIBLE). That's my job. You're an audience member. I'm there to monkey with you. That is definitely the job. OK. Laugh, laugh, laugh. Stop laughing. Stop laughing. Stop laughing. No laughing. No laughing. Laugh. All right. You know, ba, ba, ba, you're scared, be scared, OK, you said you're terrified. You're scared, you're scared, you're scared. Run. Or jump or whatever.I think one of the things that comes across from the book that I align myself with the audience almost even more than I do with other artists to some degree. That's a great night at the movies. That was worth leaving the house. That was worth spending God knows how much the movie costs to share that experience with a bunch of other strangers.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: We're going to take a turn here for a moment.

utterances.speaker: TARANTINO
utterances.sentences: Sure, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You made most of your movies with Harvey Weinstein.

utterances.speaker: TARANTINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And he's been convicted of rape. He's now on trial in California on a second sex crimes case. You heard stories about him over the years. You've said that. Why didn't you do more to try to stop him and to protect the women?

utterances.speaker: TARANTINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I never -- OK. I never heard the stories that later came out at all. I heard the same stories that everybody had heard. What I wish -- what I wish I had done was talk to Harvey about it and said, Harvey, you can't do this. This --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, what did you think this was?

utterances.speaker: TARANTINO
utterances.sentences: You know, frankly, to tell you the truth, I chalked it up to a madman era version of the boss chasing the secretary around the desk. I'm not saying that's OK. But I mean, that's how -- that's -- that's how I -- that's how I more or less -- everything I heard was more or less in that category, and as his friend, I wish I had been more of a friend and -- there was never any talk of rape or anything like that.And like the reason I didn't was because that's a real hard conversation to have because I felt it was pathetic. I felt what he was doing was pathetic and I didn't want to deal with his patheticness.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Looking back, do you have regrets and the thought -- I mean, when you say chasing the secretary around the desk, it's one thing. Obviously you say you didn't know how severe it was but did you think it was casting couch type stuff, kind of Hollywood lore?

utterances.speaker: TARANTINO
utterances.sentences: I thought it was the way I described it at first. I didn't think it was, OK, you do this for me or you're not going to get this movie. And I never heard any actresses say anything like that. It was just, you know, you know, just don't get in the back of a limo with him.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TARANTINO
utterances.sentences: I didn't know anything that anybody else didn't know. I'm just the one honest enough to say that, look, you know, I had heard some of these -- I had heard some of these things but not the things that came out. Just literally -- just the guy abusing his situation as, you know, as a studio head. It was easy to compartmentalize it to, you know, to some degree. Anyway, I feel bad about -- look, I feel bad about it now but what I feel bad about is I feel bad that I did not have a man-to-man talk with him about it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You are now the father of two small children. Your older child Leo is 2 and a half and you have described him as the audience you have spent your life waiting for.

utterances.speaker: TARANTINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Are you showing him movies?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You say that your next movie, your 10th, is going to be your last. Why? You're making great movies.

utterances.speaker: TARANTINO
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Well, it's -- I've been doing it for a long time. I've been doing it for 30 years and it's time to wrap up the show. You know? It's -- I've done it. I've given my -- I've given my whole life to it, you know? I didn't start a family until late in life. I've been -- I've always kind of equated -- if you're doing movies on, you know, on the level that I've been doing, actually at the level I've been allowed to do, it's -- I equate it to mountain climbing.You know, and so this movie is my Mount Everest and this movie is Kilimanjaro and this movie is Fuji and, you know, I've spent all that time on the mountain and I -- you know, like I said, I'm an entertainer. I want to leave you wanting more.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Do you have any idea what your 10th and last film is going to be?

utterances.speaker: TARANTINO
utterances.sentences: No, I don't at all because I'm also not in a giant hurry to make my last movie, either. So I've got my book. I'm doing a few other things and then I'll figure out what the next movie will be but also by the time I figure out what the next movie will be, I'll have a better idea of what even a movie is now. Right now I don't even know what a movie is.Is that something that plays on Netflix? Is that something that plays on Amazon and everyone -- and people watch it on their couch with their wife or their husband? Is that a movie? Because my last movie opened up in 3,000 theaters and played all over the world for a couple of months. So that's what I mean by diminishing returns. Now the thing is, I don't have the answer to that question but I don't think anybody else does either. I think it's a remains to be seen situation. And so by that time, I'll know what movies even are a few years from now. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Welcome back to WHO'S TALKING.Kara Swisher was one of the first reporters to take on the tech beat, interviewing titans of the industry. Today she hosts two podcasts but she got her start more than 25 years ago as a reporter in what became known as Silicon Valley. We start there. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: It was fun. It was interesting. They were -- everything was on the table and they could do anything and I think it was a much more innocent time. Money tends to mess things up rather quickly and they immediately got wealthy. But at the time they were very accessible, open to ideas, open to debate which they are not as much. Not everybody is now. And very just anything goes and I don't mean that in San Francisco style, though it's not that there is anything wrong with that. But it was sort of the idea that these were green fields and landscapes that could be built from nothing.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, to pick up on that, you became known as talking to billionaires before they were billionaires.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Here you are. I think by this point, they were billionaires. In 2007 in the only joint interview ever with Bill Gates and Steve Jobs.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Yes.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: What's the greatest misunderstanding in your relationship and about each other? What would you say would be this idea of cat fight, this idea of -- which one of the many?

utterances.speaker: STEVE JOBS, APPLE FOUNDER
utterances.sentences: We kept our marriage secret for over a decade now.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: BILL GATES, MICROSOFT FOUNDER
utterances.sentences: You know, it's been fun to work together. I actually kind of miss some of the people that aren't around anymore. You know. People come and go in this industry. It's nice when somebody sticks around.

utterances.speaker: JOBS
utterances.sentences: There is that one line in that one Beatle song, you and I have memories longer than the road that stretches out ahead, and that's clearly true here.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You know, Steve Jobs has become obviously such a mythic figure. Help us understand him not only then but through the arc of his life personally and professionally.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: I really enjoyed interviewing him a lot because he was passionate, and I think one thing that people got wrong about him was that he was heartless. I thought he had too much heart. And so he cared a lot and he didn't mind saying so. And I always appreciated that about him.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You know, he was known as being famously demanding and famously difficult.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Very.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: True?

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Define difficult. I mean, I'm not sure if I can say this word, but I have a -- I'm sorry, I can't say but I have a prick to productivity ratio and if you're a prick with a lot of productivity, I give you a little more space, and in that case, I thought he -- I think he was demanding on the products and I thought that was OK. I -- you know, there's of course all these things around his family and everything else, which I didn't cover but I felt like no, I think he was not compared to some of the high jinks today for sure, which seemed juvenile to me.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: The big story of course right now is Elon Musk and Twitter, and last year, you interviewed Elon before he took over the company about his affection for tweeting. Take a look.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Yes.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Someone explained it to me who's very close to you, saying it's your release valve, this is where you feel better?

utterances.speaker: ELON MUSK, TESLA FOUNDER
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think I said some people --

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: It's your happy place.

utterances.speaker: MUSK
utterances.sentences: Some people use their hair to express themselves. I use Twitter.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Do you regret any of it or not? You are kind of prominent.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Walk us through when you decided to do it. You go, "No, no, no."

utterances.speaker: ELON MUSK, CEO, TESLA
utterances.sentences: Well, I think about it for hours.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Do you?

utterances.speaker: MUSK
utterances.sentences: And I consult with my strategy team.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: After some of his early moves since he took over Twitter, you tweeted this, or you posted this

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Yes. He is blowing it. He is.I know him very well. I've done -- I did a podcast this week about our long relationship. We've done a lot of interviews. I think a lot of him as a visionary. I think the cars and rockets are so impressive and such achievements. But right now, the way he is behaving on Twitter, I'm not sure what's going on. It feels careless in a way that I don't think he has been like. He has always been -- tried to do his best, I think in many ways, although there's been some issues around COVID and the factories, which we've argued about and a bunch of different things. In this case, his id has completely taken over and it is out of control, and nobody is controlling it. And so I had to say it, I was particularly upset by his tweet about -- one of the first twits he did as a CEO was misinformation about the Paul Pelosi attack, and he attached it to a news source that had a ridiculous -- there's no other word to say it, anti-gay trope from the 1970s almost, it was crazy. And he did it in a way that was so careless, and never apologized. He took it down, but that kind of thing sort of was a warning signal. What the heck is happening here to this guy?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So how does this story of Musk and Twitter? How does this end?

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Well, he's got a lot of debt. That's the issue. Even though he is the world's richest man for now, because Tesla stock where he gets most of his wealth is down rather considerably, I'd like him to build the business. He's sort of -- insulting advertisers doesn't seem to be -- wouldn't be what I would do if I was --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It is not a good business plan.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Given 96 percent of their business is advertising, but he attacked them as woke, which is ridiculous. He is alienating his big users like myself and active users.We had some amazing stuff going on with Twitter Spaces, and every advertiser left us because they didn't want to be part of this. They didn't feel safe on the platform. It was a great deal that we were working on with Twitter.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Is it conceivable?

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: It could just collapse?

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Yes, of course. Yes. They've got it -- they owe -- he is going to owe debt in April and he has to have cashflow. He's got to have money.Now, he has made a lot of cuts that could help. Again, needlessly and not very nice to the people. You can you can make layoffs, everybody has to at this point in the economy, but the way he is doing it is obnoxious. I don't know how else to put it. And maybe the banks will just give him a break because he's so rich. You know, you've seen it over and over again, wealthy and powerful people get a break more than others.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Right, too big to fail.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: How concerned are you about TikTok as a national security threat?

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Very much so. I wrote a column three years ago saying I love TikTok, what a great product, I use it on a burner phone. That was the whole column, like I love it --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Literally, you will not use your regular phone.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You want to have a separate file that they can, if they penetrate --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I don't love having -- I don't Instagram either. I don't like how they use data, but that's just me. But I am very worried about the influence.Now, I did a recent interview with the COO. She's an amazing executive named Vanessa Pappas, and she is from Google. I've known her a long time. But the question is, how much influence does the Chinese government have on this app? And what could they do with it? And I'm not as much concerned of them looking at the habits of Kara Swisher who happens to like watching air fryer and, and sand cutting videos. But I do worry about the slight levels of ability to influence they could suddenly -- on Taiwan or something or things that are -- you know, what's fascinating is TikTok is the most moderated of the social networks. So that could go in lots of directions or not -- or not. But I certainly think it's appropriate that we look at how we can minimize that influence because the Chinese government is into everybody's business in China, it just is.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I read somewhere that you said that you don't really care what people think.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Yes, I don't.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And you attribute it to two things that and I want to explore that. One is you said that your dad died when you were five years old.

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And the other reason you say you don't care what people think is because you say you're gay. SWISHER

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Why would that make you not care?

utterances.speaker: SWISHER
utterances.sentences: I don't have time for that, and so I have limited time. And so I've got ask questions on the gay thing. So your own family doesn't -- is against you, you know, as opposed to other groups that get discriminated against, and it's better now, but you have to constantly be fighting ridiculously over something that you just are.And so, it sort of makes you -- it doesn't toughen you more than it is like, you know, if you don't like me for that, I don't know what to tell you. But I'm just going to keep being who I am and have kids and get married and do anything I want because if that's the way the standards you're using, I don't have time for you. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Coming up, a raw conversation with actor and singer, Billy Porter, about his traumatic upbringing, his rise to fame, and the stumbles he took on those rocky path to success.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Billy Porter has won two Tony Awards, a Grammy, and an Emmy Award and in the process has become an icon in the LGBTQ community.Billy's big break came almost 10 years ago in a show that would become a Broadway sensation. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I want to start with your breakout role as "Lola" in the 2013 Broadway hit "Kinky Boots" and we're going to kick it off with you singing, "Raise You Up." Here we go.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: Okay.[VIDEO CLIP OF "KINKY BOOTS" PLAYS.]

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: One reviewer after that show opened in Chicago said that that "Kinky Boots" would do for you what 'Funny Girl" did for Barbra Streisand and in fact, you won Best Lead Actor in a Musical.How did, at that point in your life, how did that recognition change your life?

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: It was everything. You know, I got a Tony. I got a Grammy. And everybody was finally paying attention. You know, finally, finally paying attention to me.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, let me -- let's continue.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: It opened a lot of doors.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Let's continue on that because then three years ago, you win the Emmy for Best Actor in a Drama for the show "Pose."

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And here you are as Pray Tell, a fashion designer who goes back to your home in Pittsburgh to share some shattering news with your family. Here you are.(BEGIN "POSE" VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: PRAY TELL, FICTIONAL CHARACTER
utterances.sentences: I have AIDS. I'm dying.I have been HIV-positive for six years and I didn't want to burden you all until it became serious. I know that we've already been through so much. Mommy, I'm not trying to upset you. And I'm so sorry. I'm sorry. I'm really sorry. Mommy, mommy. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: What I find -- you're affected watching that, aren't you?

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Was that close to real life?

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: Yes. You know, life imitates art.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I want to talk about that, because what I find so compelling, and so powerful about your entire story is that you built your success out of so much pain. PORTERmy life to hopefully standing at the intersection of art as a healer for trauma.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Which brings us to your memoir "Unprotected." Which is just out in paperback and I want to read something from the prologue, the very first page of this book you writeBill, what did you think was "wrong with you?" And how did the world let you know at the age of five?

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: Well, I didn't really have a language for it. In retrospect, it was my gayness. In retrospect, I was a sissy.I grew up in the Pentecostal Church and my family saw that behavior and they weren't happy with it. And like many of us, queer kids, it's from fear, right? The behavior of our caregivers, they're scared. They fear for us.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Until at the age of seven, he starts sexually abusing you. And I found that so painful because I thought, this little boy, seven- year-old Billy Porter, he just can't find a safe haven.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: There was no safety for me.I was sent to a psychologist, when I was five, for a year, every Wednesday after kindergarten because of my sissiness, and at the end of that evaluation, this man said in front of me, "Billy is fine. You just need to get a man around the house, who will teach him to be more of a man." So within a year, my mother had met and married my stepfather and when the abuse started, there was nothing violent about it. You know, people talk about grooming, I was very groomed. I felt very loved. I felt very seen. And because of what I had already gone through, my little seven-year- old mind thought, "Oh, well, these are my man lessons."

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I mean, he is abusive.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: I didn't know that it was abuse until I was 25 years old. I couldn't say the words that it was sexual abuse until I was in therapy at 25 years old and my therapist said "That's sexual abuse." And so for years, I experienced that because when I said I wanted tostop at 12, it stopped. Right? So, I experienced that as if I had control over it and that it was my choice.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And of course, it wasn't.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: No it wasn't.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You think you found your safe space in the 90s when you get into theater, but even there, you say, "I was too Black, too gay, too much." In 1997 you release an album in which you play a traditional male role.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: I love that you say "which I play." I love it.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You love it.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: I love it. Because it's true. Because it's true.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, okay, but this is what I was worried about. I was going to say words that I wouldn't understand.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: No, it is absolutely true. You can go.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: All right, let's play because here you are in a video from the album. This was the song --

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: Oh, I love this so much.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: "Show Me."

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: I can't even stand it.[VIDEO CLIP OF "SHOW ME" PLAYS.]

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, okay, now, I can say it. You're playing a heterosexual traditional R&B man.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: Yes. I am.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Why did you make that?

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: And I was good at it, too, let me just say that.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes, you were.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: Because they made me feel like I wasn't. Right?My queerness was the only thing that anybody was interested in. My voice was my savior for the entirety of my life until I got a record contract.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Why did you make that video?

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: Because that was the 90s. I really thought that the only way for me to be successful would be to play the game and do what they told me to do and what came out of that, and what changed the trajectory of my journey forever is that I did everything I was supposed to do. I did everything I was told to do.I was as straight as I couldn't be. I sang the music that I was supposed to. I showed up in the way that I was supposed to, and I failed anyway. And at the end of that journey, when it all imploded, I thought there is nothing worse than failing as somebody else. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Coming up(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: In 2007, Billy Porter was diagnosed with both diabetes and HIV. He declared bankruptcy as well. He lived on friends' couches until 2010 when he got a role in an off Broadway show.Now, more than a decade later, Billy is a hot property, fully realized as a fashion icon and an entertainment personality. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I want to put up some videos and have you to describe it.2019.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You go to the Golden Globes and here you are wearing a pink cape.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: Almost knocking Elisabeth Moss out because they were trying to rush me.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And then, there you are in a velvet gown at the Oscars a couple of months later, and I've got to say, you wear it well. You wear it splendidly.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: If fashion -- if we talk about fashion statements, with those two things, what were you saying? [19

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: Be yourself. Whatever that is, be yourself. And for me, it wasn't it -- you know, it was so organic because I've always been a fashion person. I've always been queer, it's never been about wearing dresses or anything like that.But I knew from watching the ladies in show business, that fashion was another way to express myself. In the market, it's a business decision. I'm a businessman. And it's like, what would that look like? Because I'm not going to just wear the penguin suit everywhere I go. I'm so bored with it. "The New York Times" on Sunday of the Golden Globes, said, you know, at Golden Globes' parties, Billy Porter is the winner. I was like, okay, all right, like I thought, fashion is a thing. You know, and people were saying, oh, you're going to go to the Oscars. You're going to be at the Oscars this year. I am like, I just got on a TV show. Why would I be at the Oscars? Ten days before, 12 days before I get a call to host the ABC red carpet pre-show, and I'm like, "What am I going to wear?" Because this is the moment and there I was sitting at the Christian Siriano show, and saw -- it was my first Fashion Week, and I saw all the ladies walking down, you know, all shapes, all sizes, all colors. And I remembered at the Fashion Show thinking, when I was in Drama School, we would have Oscar parties. And flippantly I would be like, I'm going to wear a gown. I'm not going to wear that penguin suit. I'm going to wear a gown to the Oscars. I'm going to just blow everybody's mind. And I say, you know, my life is in two parts. You know, B-O-A-O before Oscar, and after Oscar, it changed everything.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: That changed everything. Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: So the Oscars are in February-March. In May, at the Met Gala --

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: Well --

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean --

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: I had to keep it going.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: I was going to say. Here you are arriving as an Egyptian god, being borne by a bunch of people and there you are.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: What statement were you making there? PORTERhave silenced me. Y'all have dismissed me. I've been ignored. I've been dismissed. I've been -- you know, and it's like, "She's here now and she ain't going nowhere." Right?

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: It's like -- it's redemption. Everything I said, everything I knew, for all these decades was right. I was right.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: And everything you were.

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: Yes, I am right. I am right.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: After being told for all these years...

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: I was wrong. It is -- my queerness, I was told my queerness would be my liability from allies and haters alike, and it was for decades, until it wasn't.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: You have now won an Emmy, a Grammy, a Tony --

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: Two Tony's.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Okay. Who's counting?

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: I'm just saying. I'm just saying.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Okay. But my point is that you need -- you know where I'm going with this. You need an Oscar to pull off the EGOT -- Emmy- Grammy-Oscar-Tony Grand Slam?

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WALLACE
utterances.sentences: Honestly. How important is that to you?

utterances.speaker: PORTER
utterances.sentences: That's a tough question. You know, I'm an artist first and I will always be an artist, whether I win awards or not.With that said, yes, I want one. I'm not going to be one of those people that don't act like -- I want one, but not because of ego purposes. You know, I want one because when I get one, I get more power. The Black queer boy gets more power. In this industry, my platform expands. I get to get inside of something and continue to make a difference and continue to make a change because of the power that gives me. (END VIDEOTAPE)
